text: He shall drink of the brook in the way: therefore shall he lift up the head.
text_kjv: He shall drink of the brook in the way: therefore shall he lift up the head.
text_niv: He will drink from a brook beside the way;therefore he will lift up his head.
text_esv: He will drink from the brook by the way; therefore he will lift up his head.
text_nlt: But he himself will be refreshed from brooks along the way.He will be victorious.
text_msg: The King-Maker put his King on the throne;the True King rules with head held high!
text_nasb: He will drink from the brook by the wayside; Therefore He will lift up [His] head.
context: Psalm 110 is a messianic psalm, meaning it is believed to directly prophesy the coming of Jesus Christ. The entire psalm speaks of a powerful, divine king seated at God's right hand, ruling with authority and executing judgment. Understanding the historical and cultural context of warfare is key to grasping verse 7. Ancient Near Eastern warfare was arduous and demanding, often involving long marches under harsh conditions. Soldiers typically carried their own water supplies, and finding refreshment during battle was crucial for maintaining strength and morale. 'Drinking of the brook in the way' suggests a timely and providential provision of water to sustain the warrior king during intense combat. Water was a precious resource, particularly in arid regions. To find a brook or stream in the midst of battle would be a stroke of good fortune, signifying divine favor and provision. The image resonates with the themes of sustenance and victory. Furthermore, the phrase 'in the way' emphasizes that this provision occurs during the king's active engagement in battle, not in a time of rest or retreat. The verse highlights the king's unyielding commitment to the task at hand, sustained by God's grace even in the thick of the conflict. Psalm 110 was likely used in royal coronation ceremonies, reminding the king of his divine mandate and the promise of God's assistance in fulfilling his responsibilities.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 110:7 points to the sustaining power of God in the midst of Christ's earthly ministry and ultimate victory over sin and death. 'He shall drink of the brook in the way' symbolizes Christ's dependence on the Father and the spiritual nourishment He received during His earthly journey. This 'brook' can be interpreted as the Holy Spirit, the Word of God, or even the fellowship He shared with His disciples. It represents the resources available to Christ to empower Him for His mission. Jesus, even in His divine nature, chose to experience human limitations and depend on God for strength and guidance. This act of drinking is not one of desperation but of humble reliance. 'Therefore shall he lift up the head' signifies the resulting triumph and exaltation. Because Christ faithfully drew from the Father's provision, He was able to complete His redemptive work and ascend to His rightful place at the Father's right hand. The 'lifting up of the head' denotes victory, honor, and kingly dominion. It also symbolizes resurrection and ascension, the ultimate vindication of Christ's ministry. This verse highlights the critical link between dependence on God and ultimate triumph. Jesus' example demonstrates that even in the face of immense challenges, drawing upon the Father's grace leads to victory and exaltation. The verse foreshadows Christ's resurrection, where the brokenness of Good Friday yields to the glorious victory of Easter Sunday. His temporary 'thirst' leads to eternal glory.
application: In modern application, Psalm 110:7 offers profound encouragement for believers facing trials and challenges. We, like Christ, often find ourselves 'in the way' – facing difficulties and obstacles in our daily lives, careers, relationships, and spiritual journeys. The 'brook in the way' symbolizes the resources God provides to sustain us through these challenges. This can take many forms: prayer, Scripture, fellowship with other believers, wise counsel, and the prompting of the Holy Spirit. We must actively seek out and 'drink' from these sources of spiritual nourishment. When we feel depleted, discouraged, or overwhelmed, it is crucial to remember that God has promised to provide for our needs. Just as Christ depended on the Father, we too must cultivate a posture of humble reliance. This means acknowledging our limitations, seeking God's guidance, and trusting in His provision. The promise that 'therefore shall he lift up the head' offers hope and assurance that our faithfulness will be rewarded. As we persevere in seeking God's strength, we can expect to experience victory, restoration, and renewed purpose. 'Lifting up the head' can signify overcoming a challenge, receiving healing, experiencing reconciliation, or gaining a deeper understanding of God's will. This verse encourages us to approach our challenges with confidence, knowing that God is with us and will provide the resources we need to succeed. This also applies to our spiritual battles against temptation and sin. By drinking deeply from the well of God's grace, we find the strength to resist temptation and live a life that is pleasing to Him. Finally, it's a reminder that God's provision isn't always dramatic; sometimes it's found in the simple act of seeking Him in the midst of our daily struggles.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the promise of your provision in the midst of our struggles. We acknowledge that we often feel weak and inadequate in the face of life's challenges. Help us to remember that you are the source of our strength and sustenance. Lead us to the 'brook in the way' – to the places where we can find refreshment and renewal in your presence. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, guide us with your Word, and connect us with fellow believers who can offer support and encouragement. Grant us the faith to trust in your provision, even when we cannot see the way forward. May we experience the joy of 'lifting up our heads' in victory and gratitude, knowing that you are always with us. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Engage in regular prayer, study the Bible, and seek fellowship with other Christians. These practices provide spiritual nourishment and strength. Find specific verses that speak to your situation and meditate on them. Lean on your support system for encouragement and accountability.
faqs.question: Q1: How can I practically 'drink from the brook in the way' during a difficult time?

faqs.answer: Jesus, while fully God, willingly took on human limitations to identify with us and fulfill His mission. His drinking from the brook highlights his dependence on the Father as a model for us. It showcases humility and trust in God's provision.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean that Jesus 'needed' to drink from the brook? Was He not God?

faqs.answer: The 'lifting up of the head' is a powerful symbol of resurrection. Just as Christ was sustained through His earthly ministry and then exalted, so too will believers experience resurrection and eternal life through His victory over death.
faqs.question: Q3: How does Psalm 110:7 relate to the concept of resurrection?

faqs.answer: Yes, the 'brook in the way' is a metaphorical image. It can represent any source of spiritual nourishment and strength provided by God, such as the Holy Spirit, the Word of God, prayer, or the support of fellow believers.
faqs.question: Q4: Can the 'brook in the way' represent anything other than water?

faqs.answer: This verse confronts our tendency towards self-reliance. It reminds us that even Jesus, in His humanity, depended on God. We are called to humbly acknowledge our limitations and seek God's strength, rather than relying on our own abilities alone.
faqs.question: Q5: How does this verse challenge my self-sufficiency?
